channel.title: World : NPR
channel.description: NPR world news, international art and culture, world business and financial markets, world economy, and global trends in health, science and technology. Subscribe to the World Story of the Day podcast and RSS feed.
channel.copyright: Copyright 2022 NPR - For Personal Use Only

item.title: Russia-Ukraine war: What happened today (May 3)
item.description: A roundup of key developments and the latest in-depth coverage of Russia's invasion of Ukraine.
item.content:encoded:
A roundup of key developments and the latest in-depth coverage of Russia's invasion of Ukraine.

(Image credit: Yuriy Dyachyshyn/AFP via Getty Images)
item.dc:creator: NPR Staff

item.title: Newborn twins were rescued from a warzone. Now they're stuck in bureaucratic limbo
item.description: For two parents from Chicago, getting their newborn twins safely out of Ukraine was difficult. Two months later, extracting them from Poland's bureaucracy has turned out to be even more arduous.
item.content:encoded: For two parents from Chicago, getting their newborn twins safely out of Ukraine was difficult. Two months later, extracting them from Poland's bureaucracy has turned out to be even more arduous.
item.dc:creator: Matt Ozug

item.title: Those in Kramatorsk, Ukraine, are struggling as the city runs out of food and gas
item.description: Residents of Kramatorsk in eastern Ukraine are fleeing a Russian offensive. For the few who have stayed, life can be brutal, since the city is running out of food and fuel.
item.content:encoded: Residents of Kramatorsk in eastern Ukraine are fleeing a Russian offensive. For the few who have stayed, life can be brutal, since the city is running out of food and fuel.
item.dc:creator: Tim Mak

item.title: In South Korea, K-Pop fans have something to cheer about
item.description: Although concerts have been back in South Korea since the beginning of the year, cheering was prohibited. With COVID restrictions lifting in South Korea, fans are finally allowed to cheer again.
item.content:encoded: Although concerts have been back in South Korea since the beginning of the year, cheering was prohibited. With COVID restrictions lifting in South Korea, fans are finally allowed to cheer again.
item.dc:creator: Megan Lim

item.title: As UNSC chair, U.S. plans to focus on Russia's war in Ukraine and rising food prices
item.description: The U.S. plans to use its presidency of the Security Council this month to keep the spotlight on food security, as Russia's war in Ukraine has ripple effects in global food markets.
item.content:encoded: The U.S. plans to use its presidency of the Security Council this month to keep the spotlight on food security, as Russia's war in Ukraine has ripple effects in global food markets.
item.dc:creator: Michele Kelemen

item.title: Retired colonel on the rise of javelin missiles, as Biden seeks to aid Ukraine
item.description: NPR's Ari Shapiro talks with Mark Cancian, a former Marine colonel and expert on military procurement, about Biden's request to Congress for billions of dollars to buy javelin missiles to aid Ukraine.
item.content:encoded: NPR's Ari Shapiro talks with Mark Cancian, a former Marine colonel and expert on military procurement, about Biden's request to Congress for billions of dollars to buy javelin missiles to aid Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Ari Shapiro

item.title: The complex effort to hold Vladimir Putin accountable for war crimes
item.description: Ukrainian and international experts believe it will take years, if not decades, to build cases and prosecute people. Ukraine's prosecutor general's office has opened more than 9,000 investigations.
item.content:encoded:
Ukrainian and international experts believe it will take years, if not decades, to build cases and prosecute people. Ukraine's prosecutor general's office has opened more than 9,000 investigations.

(Image credit: Franco Ordoñez /NPR)
item.dc:creator: Franco Ordoñez

item.title: The U.S. now says Russia is wrongfully detaining WNBA star Brittney Griner
item.description: Griner was arrested after authorities reportedly found vape cartridges with hashish oil in her luggage. The shift in language indicates the U.S. will work more aggressively to secure her release.
item.content:encoded:
Griner was arrested after authorities reportedly found vape cartridges with hashish oil in her luggage. The shift in language indicates the U.S. will work more aggressively to secure her release.

(Image credit: Christian Petersen/Getty Images)
item.dc:creator: Joe Hernandez

item.title: Climate scientists say South Asia's heat wave (120F!) is a sign of what's to come
item.description: Some schools have closed early for summer. More than a billion people are in danger of heat stroke. Summer's early arrival in South Asia also threatens global grain supplies.
item.content:encoded:
Some schools have closed early for summer. More than a billion people are in danger of heat stroke. Summer's early arrival in South Asia also threatens global grain supplies.

(Image credit: Rajesh Kumar Singh/AP)
item.dc:creator: Lauren Frayer

item.title: How palm oil prices are affecting the global economy
item.description: The prices of cooking oil are rising. Why that could put global security at risk.
item.content:encoded:
The prices of cooking oil are rising. Why that could put global security at risk.

(Image credit: MOHD RASFAN/AFP via Getty Images)
item.dc:creator: Paddy Hirsch

item.title: Germany pledged to 'never forget' the Holocaust. Its car companies complicate that
item.description: The Nazi legacies of Germany's wealthiest families highlight the country's challenge to make good on its commitment to "never forget" the Holocaust, according to author David de Jong.
item.content:encoded:
The Nazi legacies of Germany's wealthiest families highlight the country's challenge to make good on its commitment to "never forget" the Holocaust, according to author David de Jong.

(Image credit: Topical Press Agency/Getty Images)
item.dc:creator: Ayen Bior

item.title: More survivors are found 3 days after China building collapse
item.description: Police have arrested nine people, including the building owner, on suspicion of ignoring building codes or committing other violations.
item.content:encoded:
Police have arrested nine people, including the building owner, on suspicion of ignoring building codes or committing other violations.

(Image credit: Chen Zeguo/AP)
item.dc:creator: The Associated Press

item.title: Biden meets with parents of abducted journalist Austin Tice
item.description: President Biden met with the parents of American journalist Austin Tice, who was abducted in Syria nearly 10 years ago. He has not been heard from since. Syria has never acknowledged holding him.
item.content:encoded:
President Biden met with the parents of American journalist Austin Tice, who was abducted in Syria nearly 10 years ago. He has not been heard from since. Syria has never acknowledged holding him.

(Image credit: Bilal Hussein/AP)
item.dc:creator: The Associated Press

item.title: Russia-Ukraine war: What happened today (May 2)
item.description: A roundup of key developments and the latest in-depth coverage of Russia's invasion of Ukraine.
item.content:encoded:
A roundup of key developments and the latest in-depth coverage of Russia's invasion of Ukraine.

(Image credit: Chris McGrath/Getty Images)
item.dc:creator: NPR Staff

item.title: The war in Ukraine has the cost of bread skyrocketing in places like the Middle East
item.description: The war in Ukraine has exacerbated inflation in the Middle East, where countries rely on Russia and Ukraine for imported wheat.
item.content:encoded: The war in Ukraine has exacerbated inflation in the Middle East, where countries rely on Russia and Ukraine for imported wheat.
item.dc:creator: Peter Granitz
